facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 379 of 1957 from Bombay High Court judgment dated December 3, 1954 in F.A. No. 287 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 379 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 3, 1954, of the Bombay High Court in F. A. No. 287 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 19, 1962 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal arises out of a reference under s. 30 of the Land Acquisition Act as regards the apportionment of Rs. 35,102-10-0, the companypensation awarded for two plots of land numbered, Survey No. 37 Kambhapur and Survey No. 137 Narendra.

facts.text: Compensation of Rs. 35,102-10-0 awarded for two plots: Survey No. 37 Kambhapur and Survey No. 137 Narendra.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a reference under s. 30 of the Land Acquisition Act as regards the apportionment of Rs. 35,102-10-0, the companypensation awarded for two plots of land numbered, Survey No. 37 Kambhapur and Survey No. 137 Narendra. It is numberlonger disputed that these form part of a Watan.

facts.text: Plots form part of a Watan, no longer disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberlonger disputed that these form part of a Watan. The dispute as regards the apportionment has arisen between the Watandar and the person in actual possession of the land, the appellant before us.

facts.text: Dispute on apportionment between Watandar (landlord, respondent) and tenant (appellant in possession).

anchor.surface_text: The dispute as regards the apportionment has arisen between the Watandar and the person in actual possession of the land, the appellant before us. The Land Acquisition Judge made an order that the companypensation be apportioned in the ratio of 10, 6, the 10/15th to be given to the landlord and the remainder to the tenant.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Judge apportioned compensation 10/15th to landlord, remainder to tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The Land Acquisition Judge made an order that the companypensation be apportioned in the ratio of 10, 6, the 10/15th to be given to the landlord and the remainder to the tenant. The companyrectness of this was challenged in appeal.

facts.text: Bombay High Court apportioned compensation 55:45 landlord to tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the landlord had the right to claim that the tenant should pay enhanced rent and directed the companypensation to be apportioned in the proportion of 55 to 45 between the landlord and the tenant.

facts.text: In 1863, permanent lease executed by then Watandar to appellant's predecessors at Rs. 727/- per year.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1963 a permanent lease was executed by the then Watandar in favour of the appellants predecessors. The rent also was permanently fixed by the lease at Es. 727/- per year.

facts.text: In 1907, Watandar applied under s.9 Bombay Hereditary Offices Act to declare 1863 lease null and void.

anchor.surface_text: In 1907 the Watandar made an application under s. 9 of the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874-which is described in short as the Watan Act. In this application he asked for a declaration that the alienation by the lease of 1863 be declared null and void

facts.text: Assistant Collector rejected the application on merits.

anchor.surface_text: and the Watandar be put in possession of the land leased. The Assistant Collector, before whom the application companye up for hearing rejected the application and refused to put the Watandar in possession or to cancel the lease of 1863.

facts.text: Collector on March 16, 1908 maintained order but directed additional rent equal to cess.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Collector by his order dated March 16, 1908 maintained the Assistant companylectors order with the modification that he directed an additional amount of rent equal to the case paid on the land to be paid by the lessees.

facts.text: Government on May 23, 1911 fixed rent at Rs. 1245/4/- for lands covered by lease.

anchor.surface_text: Then the Watandar moved the Government of Bombay. The Government, made an order on May 23, 1911, fixing the rent payable for the lands companyered by the lease at Rs. 1245/4/-.

facts.text: In 1926 Watandar moved Government for further increase or restoration.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be mentioned, however, that in the year 1926 the Watandar again moved the Government for a further increase of the rent, or for the restoration of the lands

facts.text: Government in 1927 fixed rent at Rs. 4300/- and periodic revision every 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the Government made an order in 1927 fixing the rent at Rs. 4300/- and also directing that the rent leviable should be revised periodically at intervals of 10 years.

facts.text: In 1928 tenant sued Secretary of State and Watandar in First Class Subordinate Judge, Dharwar.

anchor.surface_text: In 1928 the tenant brought a suit against the Secretary of State for India and the Watandar in the Court of the First Class Subordinate Judge, Dharwar, praying for a declaration that the lands

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held lands part of Watan, 1908 order under s.9(2), 1911 ultra vires re amount, 1927 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The learned SubordiNate Judge held that the lands did form part of the Watan and that the Watan Act was applicable to these lands. He also hold that the order of the Collector in 1908, though defective in form was in substance one under s. 9, sub-s. 2 of the Watan Act and therefore it companyld number be said to be ultra vires. He also held however that the order of Government in fixing rent at RS. 1245/4/which was well above that the Collector had fixed was ultra vires but that the plaintiff was number entitled to any declaration that the Government resolution of 1911 was ultra wires because of the law of limitation. The learned Judge further held that the government resolution of 1927 was ultra vires.

facts.text: High Court in earlier appeal held 1927 ultra vires, 1911 sanction of fresh lease under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: They held in agreement with the learned Subordinate Judge that the governments order of 1927 was ultra vires. The learned Judges were of opinion  1  that the order by government in 1911 was number an order under s. 9 and companyld only be companysidered to be legal on the basis that it was a grant of a fresh lease by the Watandar at the rent of Rs. 1245/4/- with the sanction of government under s. 5 of the Watan Act

facts.text: Supreme Court holds 1911 order sanction of fresh permanent lease at Rs.1245/4/-, no right to enhance rent.

anchor.surface_text: In all these circumstances, it is reasonable to hold that by the order of 1911 the government was giving its sanction to the lease of the watan lands to the person in possession at this revised rent. In companysequence of the governments order therefore a lease came into existence at the rate of Rs. 1245/4/- in place of the old lease of 1863.

facts.text: Acquired lands: 30 acres 32 gunthas out of total Watan 400 acres.

anchor.surface_text: The rent for the entire Watan, which is stated to be 400 acres of land, being Rs. 1245/4/- the proportionate rent for the lands acquired, that is, 30 acres and 32 gunthas works out at about Rs.95/9/-

facts.text: Apportionment: Rs.2389/1/- (capitalized rent at 25 times) to respondent (landlord), remainder to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The capitalised value of this at twenty- five times, amounts to Rs-2389/1/-. The apportionment should therefore be that Rs.2389/1/of the amount of companypensensation be awarded to the respondent and the remainder to the appellant.

concepts.interpretation: If the final decision in any matter at issue between the parties is based by a Court on its decisions on more than one point-each of which by itself would be sufficient for the ultimate decision-the decision on each of these points operates as res judicata between the parties.

concepts.unlisted_description: Collector may recover full rent instead of possession after declaring alienation void

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of the Watan Act is in these words Whenever any watan or, any part thereof, or any of the profits thereof, whether assigned as remuneration of an official or not, has or have, before the date of this Act coming into force, passed otherwise than by virtue of, or in execution of, a decree or order of any British Court and without the consent of the Collector and transfer of ownership in the Revenue records, into the ownership or beneficial possession of any person not a watandar of the same watan, the Collector may, after recording his reasons in writing declare such alienation to be null and void, and order that such watan, or any part thereof, or any of the profits thereof, shall from the date of such order belong to the watandar previously entitled thereto, and may recover and pay to such watandar any profits thereof accordingly. If such part of a watan be land, it shall be lawful for the Collector, instead of transferring the possession of the land, to demand and recover the full rent ordinarily paid by tenants of land of similar description in the same locality, and the amount so recovered shall be considered as the profits. The decision of the Collector as to what is the full rent shall be final

concepts.interpretation: Requires first a declaration that alienation is null and void; sub-s(2) allows recovery of full rent only after such declaration, treating possession as permissive not leasehold.

concepts.unlisted_description: Sanction required for Watandar to lease beyond natural life

anchor.surface_text: s.5 of the Watan Act. That section provides that without the sanction of the State Government it shall not be competent to a Watandar to mortgage, charge, lease or alienate, for a period beyond the terms of his natural life, any watan or any part thereof, or any interest therein, to or for the benefit of any person who is not a watandar of the same watan.

concepts.interpretation: By necessary implication authorises State Government to sanction such lease; court holds 1911 order is sanction for fresh permanent lease at revised rent.

issues.text: The real question in controversy is whether at the date of the acquisition, the landlord the Watandar had any right to enhance the rent in respect of these lands.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision this appeal has been preferred on certificate granted by the High Court. The real question in companytroversy is whether at the date of the acquisition, the landlord  the Watandar  had any right to enhance the rent in respect of these lands.

holdings.text: The 1908 order of the Collector did not declare the 1863 lease null and void and thus was not an order under s.9(2) of the Watan Act.

anchor.surface_text: The relief which a Watandar can obtain under this section is in the first place a declaration... There is number justification... to hold that when the Collector made the order that an additional amount of rent equal to the cess be paid he must have had in mind the provisions of s.9 2

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 requires explicit recording of reasons and declaration of alienation null and void before recovering full rent as profits; 1908 order lacked any such declaration and affirmed rejection of nullity.

holdings.text: The 1911 Government order was not an action under s.9 of the Watan Act.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up to the government... the government ordered -The rent should therefore number be revised and fixed at Rs. 1245/4/-... Such action can number by any stretch of imagination be considered to be an action under s.9 of the Watan Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No declaration of nullity; order revised rent assuming continuing tenancy, not treating possession as permissive after voiding lease.

holdings.text: The 1911 Government order sanctioned a fresh permanent lease under s.5 of the Watan Act at Rs.1245/4/- in place of the 1863 lease.

anchor.surface_text: The only legal basis that can be found for the governments action is in s.5 of the Watan Act. That section provides that without the sanction of the State Government... By necessary implication this section authorises the State Government to sanction...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 prohibits permanent leases without government sanction but implies authority to grant it; circumstances show sanction for revised permanent rent to continuing possessor.

holdings.text: The Watandar (landlord) had no right to enhance the rent under the lease sanctioned by the 1911 order.

anchor.surface_text: If that be the position is the Watandar entitled to increase his rent? ... the other terms, namely , that the lease was permanent and the rate of rent would remain fixed from the date of creation of the lease remained unaltered. ... The Watandar had therefore no right to increase the rent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1911 sanction modified only rent term of prior permanent fixed-rent lease; other terms including permanence and fixity unchanged.

holdings.text: In apportionment of compensation under Land Acquisition Act s.30, landlord entitled only to capitalised value of fixed rent proportionate to acquired land (annual rent x 25).

anchor.surface_text: the respondent being the landlord, is entitled to only the capitalised value of the rent. The rent for the entire Watan, which is stated to be 400 acres of land, being Rs. 1245/4/- the proportionate rent for the lands acquired,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No enhancement right means landlord interest limited to fixed rent stream, capitalized for acquisition.

holdings.text: Compensation of Rs.35,102-10-0 apportioned as Rs.2,389-1-0 to respondent (landlord) and remainder to appellant (tenant).

anchor.surface_text: The capitalised value of this at twenty- five times, amounts to Rs-2389/1/-. The apportionment should therefore be that Rs.2389/1/of the amount of companypensation be awarded to the respondent and the remainder to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionate annual rent Rs.95/9/- for acquired 30a 32g out of 400a Watan x 25 = Rs.2389/1/- to landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that out of the amount of companypensation awarded for these lands, the respondent being the landlord, is entitled to only the capitalised value of the rent. directions: compensation to be apportioned Rs.2389/1/- to the respondent and the remainder to the appellant
